article.text: On paper, Vivo’s new V11 is very similar to the X21 I tested earlier this year. It has an in-display fingerprint scanner, dual rear cameras and a beautiful glass body. Best of all, it is more affordable at only S$599. But how does the Vivo V11 perform in real life? Is it better than the X21?
Availability & Pricing – More Affordable Than the X21!

At launch, the X21 was S$799. The new V11 is available for just S$599 at M1, StarHub and Challenger. That’s a whopping S$200 difference. How is this possible? How did Vivo keep the best features from the X21, yet reduce the price by so much? I spent a week with the Vivo V11 and here is my review.

Like the X21, the Vivo V11 sold in Singapore has 6GB RAM and 128GB of internal storage. Vivo has dropped the X21’s pricing to S$599. But with all the improvements on the V11 as seen below, there isn’t really a reason why anyone would go for the X21 instead. Hmm…
Accessories & Unboxing – Where to Buy Vivo V11’s Accessories?

Vivo V11 comes in a rather standard white box. Inside, there is some paperwork, a clear case, wall adapter and charging cable, a pair of earphones and the device itself. A TPU screen protector has been pre-applied. All the basic accessories are included. Great job Vivo!

Speaking of screen protector, I accidentally got mine scratched and needed a replacement. But searching around, I could not find a single shop that had one. Many shops told me to use an OPPO R17 screen protector instead, but the shape of the notch did not match and that looked really ugly.

Thankfully, I found a OnePlus 6T screen protector that had a notch cut-out matching the V11, at a shop on level 4 of Sim Lim Square. I don’t remember the shop’s name, but here is the packaging the screen protector came in. This is probably the only one in Singapore right now…

From this incident, it is clear that Vivo hasn’t received the “mainstream” recognition from local mobile shops yet. That makes finding accessories for Vivo phones really hard. Vivo needs to bring in their own accessories, and if possible, have those accessories available in stores at launch.
Update: Vivo offers a one-time free screen replacement for the V11 within the first 3 months of purchase. This is one less reason to be afraid of dropping your V11 without a screen protector.

On the rear, Vivo V11 looks identical to the X21. It has a beautiful glass body with curved sides and the dual camera is still in the same place. This makes it really comfortable to hold. One tiny complain I do have though is that the transition between the glass back and metal frame is a little sharp.

The biggest difference in the rear design has to be the color options. The X21 came in just black. The new V11 is available in 2 beautiful gradients: Starry Night and Nebula. My review unit is the Nebula version, which is beautiful, but I prefer the Starry Night version I saw at SITEX earlier.

On the bottom, we have a headphone jack, a Micro USB port and a single speaker grill. Yep, still Micro USB. The SIM tray has been shifted to the left. It has two nano SIM slot, as well as a dedicated MicroSD card slot, so now you don’t have to choose between a second SIM card and more storage.

Vivo V11’s display is 6.41″, slightly larger than the X21’s 6.28″ due to a taller 19.5:9 aspect ratio. Immediately, you will notice that the notch of the V11 is much smaller, only housing a single selfie camera. The earpiece and proximity sensor have been shifted to the edge on top.

Its bezels and bottom chin are pretty small too, so watching videos and gaming on the V11 should feel really immersive. To make use of all the screen space, you will want to enable full screen under “Third-party app display ratio” in the settings app. By default, content cuts of at the notch in landscape mode.

This FHD+ Super AMOLED display has great viewing angles, pleasant colors and is bright enough to be visible under the sun. It is a little on the cool side, but that can be adjusted in the settings app. As expected from AMOLED, blacks are really deep.

We finally get always-on display on the Vivo V11, something that was missing on the X21 when I tested it earlier this year. And for a new feature, Vivo killed it! There is a ton of customization options, from clock style to background design. This drains the battery faster, but it looks super cool!
Performance – Fast & Smooth, as Expect from Snapdragon 660

Powered by the Snapdragon 660 AIE with 6GB RAM, the Vivo V11 can run most games without a hitch. Scrolling through the UI and browsing social media was butter smooth. PUBG Mobile runs without stutter on HD with smooth graphics, the highest I could go on this device.

In AnTuTu, V11 scored a very respectable 129394. Meanwhile, AnTuTu gave it a score of 1449 for single-core and 5534 for multi-core. It isn’t the most powerful device in its segment, but it is good enough for most users. If you are a hardcore gamer, you should look somewhere else.
Rear Cameras – Solid Hardware with Smart Software

On the rear of the Vivo V11 are a pair of 12 + 5MP cameras. Are they any good? Taking a couple of moving shots in the day, you will be surprised at how quick it focuses and captures the subject. Not only do the results look sharp and in focus, colors also look very pleasing.
At night, shutter speed is longer, but the results are often still very amazing for the price. There is a bit of noise, but it is not overbearing and images still have quite a bit of details.

One cool new feature on the Vivo V11 is AI portrait framing. The app provides suggestions of how you can frame your subject when it detects a face. Like on many devices, AI is also used to detect the type of object/scene and make the photo look more pleasing.

Moving on to videos. The V11 can record up to 4K videos, but stabilization only works up to FHD. Even then, stabilization isn’t great and there seems to be a little bit of over-sharpening. At night, a lot of details is lost and there is plenty of noise, but colors still look really good.

On the front is a 25MP shooter. Photos it takes have pleasant colors and very good dynamic range for a front-facing camera. As usual though, the rear cameras are still better. There is a “selfie lighting” feature with many lighting “filters”, including one that makes your background monochrome.

There is also a group selfie feature where you twist the phone to capture multiple shots. The phone will stitch them together like a panorama. It works in both portrait and landscape mode. The app stitches the photos perfectly, but the result has a lower resolution. Strange.
The front shooter can record videos up to FHD. Videos turn out pretty good for a front-facing camera, with great colors and the subject in focus. That said, dynamic range can be better.
Battery & Charging – A Full Day on Moderate Usage

Occasionally gaming on the Vivo V11, I drained the battery down to 7% by 9:40PM, after a 15h day. Note that always-on display was enabled. Using RF service and phone idle service duration, I estimate screen-on time to be 4h 11min. For most users, the battery should last a full day.
Usage: 2h 4min PUBG Mobile, 27min Facebook, 17min Browser, 1h 50min music playback

The V11 uses a fast charging technology called dual-engine quick charge, which requires the use of the included wall adapter. Using the included wall adapter, the V11 charged from 5% to 80% in an hour.
Unlocking Methods – A Lot More Usable!

When I tested the Vivo X21, I complained that its in-display fingerprint scanner is too slow and inaccurate. The Vivo V11 has that too, but thankfully it is way better. It may only be slightly faster, but it is recognizes my fingerprint much more often now. I was able to set it up on my first attempt.
If you do get a Vivo V11 for yourself, do not be fooled by the unlocking animation. You do not have to wait for the phone to unlock before releasing your finger. A 0.5 second tap will do.

Another way you can unlock your Vivo V11 is through face unlock. It works really well no matter the lighting condition, even from a distance. It is so quick to unlock that I often accidentally unlock the device. Sometimes being too fast isn’t a good thing…

Vivo V11 runs FunTouch OS 4.5 on top of Android 8.1 out of the box. Vivo added a few new features since my X21 review, but most of my complains with FunTouch OS are still not fixed. The awful app naming is still here, split screen support is still very limited, etc…

I love the new interface for game assistant. Not only does it look cooler, it allows you to change the settings every time you enter the game. No need to open the settings app. Need to change something while in game? Just swipe from the notch side of the display. Convenient!

The other cool new feature is that customizable always-on display, from background designs to font colors. Many phones have always-on displays, but none that I have seen have this level of customization. I wish that Vivo would add the option to use our own background images.

I hope to see a Vivo physical store in Singapore, or at least an official Lazada store, so that customers will have somewhere to buy accessories for their Vivo devices. Right now, Vivo isn’t popular enough for neighborhood shops to stock up on accessories for their products.

Next, I would like to see Vivo simplify FunTouch OS. It is nice to see new features every update, but refining the software experience is equally important. Without that, the software would only feel bloated. I recommend taking the next update to reorganize everything and improve on current features.

Lastly, Vivo should stop shipping phones with Micro USB ports, at least on phones that costs over S$500. A year ago, this would be fine. But it has been 4 years since USB Type-C was announced and there is no more excuse to not switch. Hope the next V series device will have USB Type-C.
